   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, known pleural effusions, admitted
   with worsening shortness of breath and LE swelling x 1 month.
   .
   #  DYSPNEA: Primary complaint on admission.  Likely related to
   recurrent pleural effusion, bradycardia, hypoalbuminemia [**12-30**] poor
   nutrition and some element of medication noncompliance which may be
   worsening his COPD control.  No e/o of decompensated heart failure on
   exam or CXR, BNP lower than prior baseline.  Could consider ACS but no
   chest pressure. Bradycardia resolved ON w/ HR 70-80s
   - Continue Albuterol, Tiotroprium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone; start
   scheduled Albuterol
   - Supplemental oxygen
   - Consider thoracentesis for symptomatic benefit today
   .
   #  Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy.  No h/o
   ischemia. EF 35%. BNP > 15,000 but lower than prior admission.  JVP not
   elavated and no e/o CXR.  Pulmonary exam with diminished sounds at
   bases [**12-30**] effusions, which may be due to CHF.  LE edema likely
   multifactorial and not [**Last Name (un) 6759**] attributable to CHF
   - Held BP medications given normotensive (Hydralazine / Imdur) o/n
   can restart this AM
   - Hold Diltiazem / Metoprolol given bradycardia yesterday. But will
   reconsider restarting beta blocker (low dose) if HR continues to be
   stable.
   - Hold Lasix given mild hypovolemia
   - Daily ASA
   .
   #  CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization.  No prior ischemic
   events. No plan to cath at this time.
   - ASA daily
   .
   #  PUMP: History of Systolic CHF; Ef = 30%.  NO e/o volume overload at
   this time.
   .
   #  RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation with decreased ventricular response.
   - Hold rate controlling agents given bradycardia
   .
   #  ARF: Unclear etiology.  Worsened from prior baseline.  Appears
   intravascularly dry on exam. CXR without volume overload.  Denies any
   dsyuria.
   - FeNa 1%
   - IVF o/n and Cr trend improved slightly.
   - Will continue to trend Cr
   .
   #  Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis: With elevated lactate, low
   bicarbonate. On prior admission, resolved with fluid resuscitation.
   Some component of dehydration.  Lactate may be related to poor liver
   function.
   - Responded well to fluid resuscitate. Will trial PO today.
   - Trend lactate
   - Monitor labs
   .
   #  Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures.  Patient states
   seizures are unrelated and he gets them when he's 'hot and cold.
   description suggestive of rigors vs. seizures.  SW consult ordered
   today
   - MVI, thiamine, folate
 f/u labs
   - CIWA with Valium
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   .
   #  Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels.  No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation - Rate well-controlled on diltiazem and
   metoprolol. Continued aspirin. Coumadin therapy deferred due to
   patient preference and concerns regarding  medication and
   monitoring noncompliance.
   - Rate &0s, well controlled this morning
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II - On Metformin in [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be contributing
   to Lactic acidosis.
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, Spiriva, and Albuterol prn.
   .
   #  Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Suspect [**12-30**] hypovolemia and
   malnutrition from chronic alcoholism.  Calculated sodium deficit
   recommends 160cc/hr of NS x 16 hours to reach 130; will give more
   slowly given CHF
   - Continue IV NS (~75cc/hr) to replete sodium
   - Continue to monitor labs; recheck lytes
   .
   # Abdominal Pain: Patient stated pain is diffuse and chronic but
   resolved o/n.  Also with some nausea prior to admission w/ some
   sputum/clear fluid emesis this AM.
   - Zofran PRN nausea
   .
   #  Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia.  [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   #  Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion -  Previously evaluated for this.  On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge.  Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Consider thoracentesis today
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules -  Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Gentle IVF/replete Mg/regular diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2200-6-1**] 10:34 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2200-6-1**] 10:35 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: IV Heparin
   Stress ulcer: Omeprazole 20mg Qdaily
   Pain:
   Bowels: Docusate PRN
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: Pt states there is no one he would like us to
   call
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: Call out to floor
Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), known pleural effusions, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient was admitted with worsening shortness of breath and lower extremity (LE) swelling for one month.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 127/73 mmHg to 103/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on nasal cannula. The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a decreased ventricular response.

On physical examination, the patient appears well-nourished but mildly agitated, with occasional non-productive cough and difficulty breathing. The patient is oriented to time, place, and person. There are no signs of pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Sclera is anicteric, pupils are equal and reactive, and conjunctiva are pink. The neck is supple with a jugular venous pressure (JVP) of 8 cm. Cardiac examination reveals a point of maximal impulse (PMI) located in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line, with normal S1 and S2 sounds. No murmurs, gallops, or lifts are appreciated. Lung auscultation

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), known pleural effusions, and admitted with worsening shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling for one month. He is currently in the ICU.

Vital Signs:
- Temperature: 36.6°C (97.9°F)
- Heart Rate: 70 bpm (with atrial fibrillation)
- Blood Pressure: 127/73 mmHg (with occasional readings below 100 systolic)
- Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths per minute
- Oxygen Saturation: 95% on nasal cannula

Physical Examination:
- General: Well-dressed, mildly agitated, stating difficulty breathing, oriented x3.
- HEENT: No abnormalities noted.
- Neck: Supple with jugular venous distension (JVD) of 8 cm.
- Cardiac: Point of maximal impulse (PMI) located in the 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. Regular S1 and S2 sounds without murmurs, lifts, or thrills. No signs of heart failure.
- Lungs: Mild end-expiratory wheeze bilaterally, no crackles or rhonchi.
- Abdomen: Soft, diffusely tender to palpation without localization. No hepatosplenomegaly (HSM).
- Extremities: 2+ bilateral

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), known pleural effusions, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He presents with worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and mild agitation. The patient has received Valium for hallucinations and agitation. He also requested an albuterol inhaler.

Vital signs show a heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 127/73 mmHg to 103/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 95%, and temperature within normal limits. The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a decreased ventricular response.

Physical examination reveals no chest wall deformities or signs of distress. The patient has mild expiratory wheezes, decreased breath sounds at the bilateral bases, and 2+ edema in the lower extremities. There are no stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. 

Laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine (Cr), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), lactate, and liver enzymes (AST, ALT). The patient has an anion gap metabolic acidosis with elevated lactate, low bicarbonate, and elevated white blood cell count (WBC). The platelet count is also decreased.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Dyspnea: The primary complaint

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, initially managed with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure. The patient's current condition includes dyspnea, hypoxia, and recurrent left pleural effusion. He also has anemia, diabetes mellitus type II, hyponatremia/hypochloremia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated INR.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's hypoxia and decreased oxygen saturation may progress to ARDS if not properly managed.
2. Cardiac Tamponade: The patient's history of CHF and recurrent pleural effusion increases the risk of cardiac tamponade.
3. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient's elevated INR and history of alcohol abuse raise concerns for hepatic dysfunction and potential development of hepatic encephalopathy.
4. Seizures: The patient's history of alcohol abuse and DTs with seizures indicates a risk for recurrent seizures.
5. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobilization and history of alcohol abuse increase the risk of developing DVT.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's impaired

   Assessment and Plan
 .H/O HEART FAILURE (CHF), SYSTOLIC, CHRONIC
 .H/O CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS,
   EMPHYSEMA) WITH ACUTE EXACERBATION
 .H/O ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
 .H/O ALCOHOL ABUSE
   59 yo M with PMH of systolic CHF, hx of transudative pleural effusions,
   admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF initially managed
   with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure transferred to MICU for
   hypoxia.
   .
   # DYSPNEA/HYPOXIA: Physical exam on presentation to CCU interpreted as
   intravascular depletion b/c no JVP and no signs of pulm vasc
   congestion. That said, multiple other findings pointing to acute on
   chronic CHF. Failure of initial mgt with fluid resuscitation (2L)
   supports this as evidenced by worsened CXR and oxygen requirement.
   Also evidence of PNA on CXR.
   - Continue Albuterol, Ipratropium and Salmeterol-Fluticasone
   - If worsening resp status will need to intubate.
   - diuresis with lasix bolus + drip goal out 2L+ per day.
   - CAP: start ceftriaxone, azithromycin and vanco (given hx of MRSA).
   .
   # Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology, though likely some component of
   alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy per cards. No
   h/o ischemia. BNP > 15,000, that it is somewhat lower than prior
   admissions is likely of little significance.
   - restart afterload reduction with hydralazine (unclear why he is not
   on an [**Name (NI) **], no allergy listed); hold long acting nitrate
   - Metoprolol restarted for rate control and improved diastolic filling
   time
   - diuresis as above  (-2L goal)
   .
   # Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures. ETOH on admission 205
   - MVI, thiamine, folate; check B12
   - CIWA with Valium
   - SW consult
   - Seizure / aspiration precautions
   # Recurrent left pleural effusion - Previously evaluated for this. On
   last admission, underwent left-sided diagnostic and therapeutic
   thoracentesis on [**2200-4-14**] with removal of 2.3L transudative fluid.
   Cytology negative for malignant cells. Attributed to chronic systolic
   CHF and medication noncompliance. Added hydralazine and isosorbide for
   better afterload reduction. Adequate room air ambulatory oxygen
   saturation prior to discharge. Now readmitted with worsened effusion,
   dyspnea and new O2 requirement.
   - Continue diuresis
   .
   # CORONARIES: No prior cardiac catheterization. No prior ischemic
   events.
   - ASA daily (DMII)
   .
   # RHYTHM: Atrial fibrillation initially with decreased ventricular
   response, now HR in 80-90 range.
   - continue holding dilt, restarted metoprolol
   - no coumadin per previously expressed pt preference, continue ASA 325
   daily
   .
   # ARF: Attributed to hypovolemia on admission; more likely to poor
   forward flow in setting of fluid overload; may have been exacerbated by
   bradycardia. Improving. Continue to monitor.
   .
   # Anemia: Normocytic and similar to prior levels. No e/o acute blood
   loss, patient refused rectal exam in ED.
   - Trend, if worsens will T&C
   - Guaiac stools
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus type II
   - ISS with FS QACHS
   - Hold Metformin
   .
   # Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Complaining of dyspnea as
   above, likely multifactorial.
   - Continue Advair, and Albuterol prn. Ipratrop over Spiriva as inpt
   .
   # Hyponatremia / Hypochloremia: Beer potomania? Could also be from poor
   forward flow in setting of acute on chronic CHF or liver dz;
   hypovolemic hyponatremia.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: New thrombocytopenia. [**Month (only) 60**] represent overall poor
   hepatic function.
   - Trend, avoid medications that worsen
   .
   # Elevated INR: Concerning for worsened hepatic function; also with
   likely some element of malnutrition.
   - Trend coagulopathy
   .
   # Mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules - Noted on prior
   admission, recommended follow-up CT in 3 months.
   .
   FEN: Gentle IVF / replete Mg / NPO
   .
   ACCESS: PIV
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with SQH, pending troponin downward trending
   -Bowel regimen with Docusate PRN
   CODE: FULL CODE (confirmed on admission)
   COMM: Pt states there is nobody he would like us to call
   DISPO: ICU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO

4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has new-onset thrombocytopenia, which could be due to poor forward flow in the setting of acute on chronic CHF or liver disease.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and worsening respiratory status may require intubation and mechanical ventilation to support his breathing.

3. Pleural effusion: The patient has a history of recurrent left pleural effusion, which can worsen due

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), alcohol abuse, and transudative pleural effusions. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF initially managed with fluids resulting in worsening heart failure. He is now in the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypoxia. The patient has multiple comorbidities, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus type II, and dyspnea/hypoxia likely due to CHF exacerbation and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's worsening respiratory status and hypoxia could lead to ARDS, a life-threatening condition characterized by severe lung inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Being intubated for over 48 hours increases the risk of developing VAP, which is a type of lung infection that occurs in people receiving mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation (AF) and ongoing hypoxia may increase the risk of further cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's decreased urine output (UOP) and elevated creatinine levels suggest the possibility of AK

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of shortness of breath. The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation, and alcohol abuse. Upon admission, the patient required invasive ventilation, and various lines were placed including an arterial line and multi-lumen line. The patient also underwent cultures, specifically sputum and urine cultures. The patient's vital signs include a heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 112/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's temperature is within normal range at 36.5 degrees Celsius. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's requirement for invasive ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP. This can be prevented by maintaining head-of-bed elevation, performing regular mouth care, and ensuring appropriate antibiotic therapy.

2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of developing DVT. Prophylactic measures such as subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin should be administered.

3. Stress ulcers: Critically ill patients, especially those receiving mechanical ventilation, are at increased risk of stress ulcers. Prophylactic treatment with proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) should be initiated to

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), transudative pleural effusions, admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF. The patient was initially managed with fluids but resulted in worsening heart failure. He was transferred to the MICU for hypoxia.

The patient is currently on invasive ventilation with a PEEP of 10 and FiO2 of 50%. He has a central line placed in the left internal jugular vein, a multi-lumen line, arterial line, and Foley catheter. He is receiving antibiotics for suspected community-acquired pneumonia (ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and vancomycin) and medications for systolic CHF (hydralazine and metoprolol).

The patient has a history of alcohol abuse with reported delirium tremens and seizures. Ethanol was found on admission, and the patient is receiving multivitamins, thiamine, and folate. Social work recommendations are pending, and seizure/aspiration precautions are in place.

The patient has a history of recurrent left pleural effusion, which was tapped in April or May and found to be transudative in nature. Diuretics are being continued.

The patient initially had atrial fibrillation with decreased ventricular response but now has a heart rate in the 80-90 range. Metoprolol

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, managed with fluids but resulting in worsening heart failure. He was intubated due to worsening respiratory status and is currently on mechanical ventilation. He has been diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and chronic kidney disease (CKD). The patient's current medications include fentanyl, midazolam, haloperidol, metoprolol, albuterol, ipratropium, ceftriaxone, and azithromycin.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration. Close monitoring and weaning off mechanical ventilation will be necessary.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of systolic CHF and AF. Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart block, or worsening heart failure may occur. Monitoring of heart rate and blood pressure is essential, and medications like metoprolol will be continued.
3. Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with CAP. There is a risk of progression or development of other infections, especially due to his immunocompromised state. Continued monitoring

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF, initially managed with fluids but resulted in worsening heart failure. He was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for hypoxia. The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, acute-on-chronic CHF, anemia, pneumonia, community-acquired (CAP), and other cardiomyopathy. He has also had recurrent left pleural effusion, alcohol abuse, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure (ARF), and diabetes mellitus type II.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Worsening heart failure: The patient's CHF exacerbation may lead to further fluid accumulation and respiratory distress.
2. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to being intubated for respiratory support.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count indicates potential bleeding risks and needs monitoring.
4. Elevated INR: The increased INR suggests impaired liver function and an increased risk of bleeding.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's elevated INR and anemia may indicate malnutrition, which can complicate recovery.
6. Alcohol withdrawal

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and diabetes mellitus type II. He presented with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF, which resulted in worsening respiratory status. The patient was intubated and transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypoxia. He has since developed respiratory failure, anemia, pneumonia, and cardiac complications related to his pre-existing conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's worsening respiratory status and the need for intubation indicate a high risk for developing ARDS.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): Due to the prolonged duration of mechanical ventilation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP.
3. Sepsis: The presence of pneumonia and the use of antibiotics suggest a risk of developing sepsis.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of CHF, AF, and alcohol abuse puts him at risk for further cardiac complications such as heart failure exacerbation, arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
5. Thromboembolic Events: Immobility and the presence of thrombocytopenia increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary emb

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and type II diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF, managed with fluids resulting in worsening heart failure. The patient then developed hypoxia and was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypoxia.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, acute on chronic CHF, anemia, pneumonia (community-acquired), and possible components of alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachycardia. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. He is receiving antibiotics for his pneumonia and diuretics for CHF. The patient also has a history of recurrent left pleural effusion, for which he had a chest tube placement. Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and alcohol abuse. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic heart failure, initially managed with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure. He was transferred to the MICU for hypoxia due to likely CHF exacerbation and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient has a history of transudative pleural effusions and is currently experiencing a large left pleural effusion. Continuous monitoring for changes in chest X-ray and consideration of a repeat CT scan without contrast due to prior CT showing trapped lung are recommended.

2. Systolic CHF: The patient's systolic CHF is of unclear etiology, possibly involving alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachy-myopathy. Management includes continuing metoprolol, holding hydralazine as the patient is normotensive, discontinuing Lasix gtt and providing boluses as needed, and considering an ACE inhibitor in the long term.

3. Alcohol Abuse: The patient has reported a history of delirium tremens with seizures and appears to be over this window. Continued MVI, thiamine, and folate supplementation, as well as follow-up B12 levels and social work recommendations, are necessary.

4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's heart rate remains elevated, and an increased dose of metoprolol is recommended to control the heart rate. Holding off on restarting diltiazem and considering anticoagulation therapy with coumadin should be discussed with the patient.

5. Acute Respiratory Failure (not ARDS): The patient is currently ventilated well on assist-control mode with a tidal volume of 550 mL and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. Weaning to pressure support ventilation (PSV) is planned. Albuterol and ipratropium nebulizations will continue for COPD management. Ceftriaxone will be continued for CAP, and another sputum culture will be obtained.

6. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is currently 23.8%. Transfusion is indicated if Hct drops below 21. Guaiac stool testing should be done to assess for gastrointestinal bleeding.

7. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: The patient is currently on insulin secretagogues (ISS).

8. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease: Continued management with albuterol and ipratropium nebulizations is recommended.

9. Hyponatremia/Hypochloremia: Hyponatremia has resolved, and continued monitoring to see if it corrects with diuresis is advised. Lytes should be checked regularly.

10. Thrombocytopenia: Platelet levels should

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with multiple comorbidities, including chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), alcohol abuse, and a history of atrial fibrillation. The patient was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure secondary to acute exacerbation of COPD and pneumonia. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube. His vital signs show tachycardia and hypertension. The patient has a positive fluid balance. Laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count, elevated troponin-T, elevated lactate level, and elevated levels of several enzymes. The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism due to immobility and central venous catheters.
3. Nosocomial infection, such as catheter-related bloodstream infection.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, due to underlying cardiac dysfunction and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypoperfusion or nephrotoxic medications.
6. Stress ulcer due to increased gastric acid production caused by critical illness and corticosteroid use.
7. Barotrauma or bronchopleural fistula from high-pressure

   hypoxia.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, alcohol abuse, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and type II diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic heart failure, managed with fluids resulting in worsening heart failure, and then transferred to the MICU for hypoxia. The patient has several medical complications including respiratory failure, cardiomyopathy, anemia, pneumonia (bacterial community-acquired), recurrent left pleural effusion, systolic congestive heart failure, alcohol abuse, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus type II, COPD, hyponatremia/hypochloremia, thrombocytopenia, elevated INR, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy/pulmonary nodules. The patient is currently sedated but following commands, with chest crackles, soft abdomen, and large left pleural effusion on chest X-ray. He is on multiple medications and treatments for his various conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status has worsened, leading to intubation and mechanical ventilation. There is a concern for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), but it is mentioned as "not ARDS."
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient has a history of chronic systolic heart failure and possible alcohol-related cardiomyopathy.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and other comorbidities. The patient was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF exacerbation, managed with fluids resulting in worsening heart failure, and subsequently transferred to the MICU for hypoxia.

The patient's chief complaints include dyspnea and hypoxia, likely due to CHF exacerbation and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and receiving antibiotics for CAP. The plan is to wean the patient off the ventilator on Monday.

The patient also has recurrent left pleural effusion, which was tapped previously. A CT scan without contrast will be obtained due to prior CT showing trapped lung. The decision regarding decortication or pleurodesis will be discussed with interventional pulmonology on Monday.

The patient has systolic CHF of unclear etiology, possibly involving alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachy-myopathy. The management plan includes continuing metoprolol, holding hydralazine, discontinuing lasix gtt, and providing boluses as needed. The patient may be started on an ACE inhibitor in the long term.

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), alcohol abuse, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF initially managed with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure. He was then transferred to the MICU for hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
- Cardiomyopathy, other
- Anemia, other
- Pneumonia, bacterial, community-acquired (CAP)
- History of heart failure (CHF), chronic
- History of COPD with acute exacerbation
- History of AF
- History of alcohol abuse

Assessment and plan:
1. Dyspnea/Hypoxia: Likely CHF exacerbation and CAP. Oxygenating and ventilating well, over breathing vent with Vt spontaneous 750, RR spontaneous 9, FiO2 40%, PEEP 5. Diuresing well and at goal-continue. D/c Midazolam and Fentanyl and start Propofol and Haldol prn with extubation today.
2. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: Was tapped in 4-5. Continue to monitor for changes in CXR. Will check CT without contrast due to prior CT showing trapped lung. Talk to IP/Thoracics on Monday re: Trapped lung (decortication vs. pleuridesis).
3. Systolic CHF: Unclear etiology (per cards, possibly some component of alcohol cardiomyopathy and possibly some tachy-myopathy). Will continue metoprolol and will continue to hold hydralazine, as patient is normotensive. Restarted Lasix bolus and drip, follow I/O. Pt can possibly be started on an ACEi in the long term.
4. Alcohol Abuse: Reported h/o DTs with seizures, appears he is over this window. Continue MVI, thiamine, and folate. Follow-up B12. F/u social work recs. SW says that they will see the patient when he is able to communicate.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: HR still elevated. Will cont  metoprolol 125 mg TID; per PCP this has been a problem in the past as well and he has required up to 300 mg. Will hold off on restarting diltiazem at this point. Pt not on coumadin per personal preference.
6. ARF: Current creatinine 0.9 trending down. Continue to monitor UOP, BUN, and Cr. PM lytes.
7. Anemia: Pt's hematocrit is currently 23.5. Will transfuse if Hct drops below 21. Guaiac stools.
8. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: On ISS.
9. Chronic

He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF exacerbation, managed with fluids initially but resulted in worsening heart failure. He was transferred to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) for hypoxia and is now on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient has a history of recurrent left pleural effusion and is being monitored for changes in chest X-ray. A CT scan without contrast is also planned due to prior CT showing trapped lung. The patient may require further intervention such as decortication or pleuridesis.
2. Systolic CHF: The patient's systolic CHF etiology is unclear, possibly including alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachy-myopathy. Treatment includes continuing metoprolol, holding hydralazine, providing lasix boluses as needed, and considering an ACE inhibitor in the long term.
3. Alcohol Abuse: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse with previous episodes of delirium tremens (DTs) and seizures. Treatment includes multivitamins, thiamine, folate, and follow-up B12 levels. Social work recommendations are pending when

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF, initially managed with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure. The patient is currently in the ICU for hypoxia and is on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient has a history of recurrent pleural effusions, which may require further intervention such as tapping or surgical procedures like decortication or pleurodesis.
2. Systolic CHF Exacerbation: The patient's heart failure symptoms are worsening, indicating an exacerbation of his systolic CHF. This can lead to further fluid overload, respiratory distress, and potential cardiac arrest.
3. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. If his condition does not improve, he may require prolonged mechanical ventilation or tracheostomy.
4. Bacterial Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). If left untreated or inadequately treated, it can progress to severe pneumonia, sepsis, and septic shock.
5. Alcohol Withdrawal: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and recent withdrawal

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and other comorbidities. The patient was admitted with bradycardia and acute exacerbation of CHF, initially managed with fluids resulting in worsening heart failure. He was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for hypoxia.

The patient's current condition is summarized as follows:

1. Dyspnea/Hypoxia: The patient is likely experiencing a CHF exacerbation and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). He is oxygenating and ventilating well on assisted mechanical ventilation (AC 550 x 18, PEEP 5, 40% FIO2) and continues to diurese well, with a negative fluid balance of ~2L yesterday. The plan is to attempt weaning to pressure support (PS) this morning and extubate the patient.

2. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient had a left pleural effusion that was tapped in the past. It is important to monitor for changes in chest X-ray and consider a CT scan without contrast due to a prior CT showing trapped lung. There is an ongoing discussion regarding the need for surgical intervention, such as decortication or pleurodesis, which is awaiting reply from the interventional pulmonology

Summary:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AF), and alcohol abuse. The patient was admitted to the ICU due to acute respiratory failure and required endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. The patient has been receiving sedation, diuresis with Lasix, and prophylactic heparin. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 132/73 mmHg to 160/98 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, creatinine, and lactate levels, as well as decreased platelet count. The patient has several medical problems including constipation, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, cardiomyopathy, anemia, pneumonia, chronic heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and a history of alcohol abuse. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): Immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of DVT, which can lead to PE.
3. Sepsis: With elevated white blood cell count and signs of infection, the patient is at risk for sepsis, especially considering the presence of pneumonia.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, CHF, and cardiomyopathy, increasing the risk of arrhythmias, heart failure exacerbation, or myocardial infarction.
5. Renal dysfunction: Elevated creatinine levels indicate potential renal impairment, which can be exacerbated by medications and fluid balance issues.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: Prolonged ICU stay and limited oral intake can lead to malnutrition and associated complications.
7. Pressure injuries: Immobility and prolonged bed rest increase the risk of developing pressure injuries.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulants and alcohol abuse history puts him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's condition and implement appropriate measures to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a complex medical history, including chronic systolic heart failure (CHF), atrial fibrillation (AF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), alcohol abuse, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF exacerbation initially managed with fluid resulting in worsening heart failure, then transferred to the MICU for hypoxia.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues that need to be addressed:

1. Dyspnea/Hypoxia: The patient is likely experiencing CHF exacerbation and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). He is currently oxygenating and ventilating well on assisted control ventilation (AC) with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FIO2) of 40%. It is planned to attempt extubation again today.

2. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient had a pleural effusion that was tapped on [**4-5**]. It is important to continue monitoring for changes in chest X-ray (CXR) and consider a computed tomography (CT) scan without contrast due to prior CT showing trapped lung. A discussion regarding decortication versus pleuridesis is pending.

3. Systolic CHF: The etiology of the patient's systolic CHF is unclear, possibly involving alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. Metoprolol will be continued,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and chronic kidney disease (CKD). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypoxia and worsening heart failure. The patient's current condition is stable, with controlled blood pressure and oxygenation on mechanical ventilation. He continues to diurese well and has had a negative fluid balance of 3.5 liters in the past day.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient has a history of recurrent left pleural effusions, which require ongoing monitoring for changes in chest X-ray. A computed tomography (CT) scan without contrast may be necessary due to prior CT showing trapped lung. Consultation with thoracic surgery for potential decortication or pleurectomy is being considered but may be canceled due to the patient's social situation.

2. Systolic CHF: The patient has systolic CHF with an unclear etiology, possibly including alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. Management includes continuing metoprolol, holding hydralazine, and continuing diuresis with the goal of maximum tolerated dose. Long-term consideration for starting an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) may be appropriate.

3. Alcohol Abuse: The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and reported episodes of delirium tremens (DTs) with seizures. Ongoing management includes continued multivitamins, thiamine, and folate supplementation. Follow-up on vitamin B12 levels and referral to social work for further evaluation and recommendations are necessary.

4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is well-controlled with metoprolol at a dose of 125 mg three times daily. Previous history of requiring higher doses of metoprolol for rate control is noted. Holding off on restarting diltiazem at this point is advised due to the patient's preference against anticoagulation therapy.

5. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's current creatinine level is trending down at 0.9. Close monitoring of urine output (UOP), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and creatinine is essential to assess renal function.

6. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is currently 24.9, indicating anemia. Transfusion criteria include a hematocrit below 21. Additionally, guaiac stools and peripheral smear examination should be conducted to evaluate for any bleeding or underlying causes of anemia.

7. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: The patient is being managed with insulin sensitivity syndrome (ISS).

8. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): Continued use of albuterol and ip

Summary:
Summary of the Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), alcohol abuse, and possible alcohol-related cardiomyopathy. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute exacerbation of chronic heart failure. He initially received fluid management but developed worsening heart failure and hypoxia, leading to transfer to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU).

The patient has multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, acute on chronic heart failure, pneumonia (community-acquired), recurrent left pleural effusion, and systolic congestive heart failure (CHF). Other issues include alcohol abuse, atrial fibrillation, acute renal failure (ARF), anemia, diabetes mellitus type II, COPD, hyponatremia/hypochloremia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated INR.

The patient has been extubated and is currently on lasix gtt at 15mg/hr with the goal of maximum diuresis. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient was intubated and placed on invasive ventilation until June 11th at 10:45 AM. An arterial line was also stopped on June 11th at 11:30 AM. The patient was extubated and now uses lasix gtt at a rate of 15mg/hr to achieve maximum diuresis.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and other comorbidities. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute on chronic CHF, initially managed with fluids resulting in worsening heart failure. The patient has been in the ICU for hypoxia and is currently extubated. He continues to diurese well and will attempt to be extubated again today. The patient's pleural effusion was tapped previously, and he will continue to be monitored for any changes in chest X-ray and diuresis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient had a previous pleural effusion that was tapped, and there is a concern for its recurrence. Monitoring for changes in the chest X-ray and continuing diuresis as much as tolerated is important.

2. Systolic CHF: The patient has systolic CHF with an unclear etiology, possibly including alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachycardia. Continuing metoprolol, holding hydralazine, and diurezing with the goal of maximum tolerated output are recommended.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a medical history of systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation (AF), alcohol abuse, and diabetes mellitus type II. He was admitted with bradycardia and acute-on-chronic CHF, managed with fluids initially, but resulted in worsening heart failure. The patient was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) for hypoxia and likely CHF exacerbation and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). He was extubated on 6/11 without incident and continues to diurese well. The patient's current medications include lasix, aspirin, chlorhexidine gluconate, docusate sodium, folic acid, heparin, insulin, ipratropium bromide MDI, lansoprazole, lactulose, metoprolol tartrate, multivitamins, propofol, senna, thiamine, and other medications as per the ICU care plan.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Left Pleural Effusion: The patient had a left pleural effusion in 4/5 and may require further intervention or monitoring.
2. Systolic CHF: The patient's CHF is likely due to an unclear etiology, possibly involving alcohol cardiomyopathy and tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. Management
